DOC.HEAD: Developer Picks Northern Nebraska For Nuclear Waste Dump
DOC.TEXT: A builder announced Friday the selection of a site near this tiny community for a low-level nuclear waste dump for Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. Opponents and a senator from neighboring South Dakota said they would fight the selection, but others hailed the $40 million project for the jobs and money it would bring to Boyd County in northern Nebraska. The 320-acre site about two miles west of this community of about 530 people and five miles from the South Dakota line was chosen for its geology, said US Ecology Vice President Rich Paton. Gov. Kay Orr cautioned that it would be premature to conclude that the site was acceptable until the licensing process is completed. ``A license will not be issued unless US Ecology can convince us that Nebraska's environment, and the health and safety of the citizens of Boyd County will be protected,'' Mrs. Orr said. The application won't be made before July 1990, said US Ecology spokesman Jim Neal. The reinforced, above-ground concrete vault system is expected to begin operating in 1993 and to employ 25 to 30 people. It will have a 30-year lifespan and capacity for up to 5 million cubic feet of radioactive waste, but officials estimate there will be only 50,000 to 70,000 cubic feet, Neal said. The waste, gloves and other radioactive garbage from nuclear power plants or hospitals, will come from the five states. ``I don't think we have a whole lot of people who are afraid of this thing,'' said Butte Mayor Ron Schroetlin. Schroetlin said the five-state waste compact commission had promised $300,000 a year to the area chosen until the disposal site is built and up to $2 million each year it is used. ``If that's used wisely it can help the whole county,'' he said. The site was one of three US Ecology was considering. The others were in Nuckolls and Nemaha counties in southeast Nebraska. The 500 to 1,000 feet of impermeable shale bedrock beneath the Boyd County site ``will provide a sound, natural barrier'' between it and the Dakota Sandstone aquifer, Paton said said. US Ecology is developing the site for the Central Interstate Low-Level Radioactive Waste Compact Commission. Member states voted two years ago to make Nebraska the host state. In November 1988, Nebraska voters rejected an initiative petition question to remove the state from the compact. Boyd County opponents had argued that their area contains wetlands that should be protected, but Paton said US Ecology could build without disturbing them. Harold Pierce, an area geologist who worked for the county Low-Level Radioactive Waste Monitoring Committee, said US Ecology's choice was a wise decision. ``There's not much question in my mind that that's the best site, geologically and hydrologically,'' Pierce said. Actions over the years by local opponents included boycotting businesses owned by supporters, and trying to recall a county supervisor. Last month, a jury acquitted four Boyd County men accused of confronting security guards at the gate of the proposed site, and charges were dropped against a fifth. Schroetlin said things have calmed down. ``Maybe it will fire up again,'' he said. U.S. Sen. Thomas A. Daschle, D-S.D., said he would ask the Army Corps of Engineers and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to review the decision. ``I find it incredible that the state of Nebraska can determine that a site that contains numerous federal wetlands would be acceptable for a low-level nuclear waste site,'' the senator said. Lowell Fisher, head of the Save Boyd County anti-dump group, said, ``We're going to do everything we can think of. We'll attack it legally and every other way possible. I firmly believe it won't be built here.'' Boyd County's People for Progress, a group formed about a year ago to support the waste site, welcomed US Ecology's choice. ``Now is the time for everyone to come together to work for the good of our county,'' said Ken Reiser, the group's vice chairman.
